newsitem.title: GERMANY: Continental tire pumps up first-half profit.
newsitem.headline: Continental tire pumps up first-half profit.

text.p: German tire maker Continental AG said Monday its pretax profits soared 73 percent to 208 million marks ($113 million) in the first half of 1997 and it expected a "significant rise in net profit" for the year as a whole.

The sharp profit increase, which came on sales growth of only 5 percent to 5.35 billion marks ($2.9 billion), was due to improved efficiency and strong profit growth at its Continental General Tire division, the company said in a statement to shareholders.
"Continental is on a good path," the statement said. "The goal is to make all areas of the company profitable."
Continental declined to give a specific profit figure for the year as a whole, but said it expected company sales to climb 5 percent to around 11 billion marks ($5.96 billion) in 1997.
The company had previously signalled it expected strong profit growth this year.

In April, Continental reported net profit of 192.5 million marks ($104.3 million) for 1996, up from 155.2 million ($84.1 million) in 1995. Sales rose 1.7 percent to 10.4 billion marks ($5.6 million) in 1996.

Monday's results were especially noteworthy for the increase in operating profit at U.S. unit Continental General Tire, which saw operating profit surge to 63 million marks ($34 million) from 39 million marks ($21 million) in the first half of 1996.
